youth, greeue, be effeminate, changeable, longing, and
liking, proud, fantaſtical, apiſh, ſhallow, inconſtant, ful
of teares, full of ſmiles; for euerie paſſion ſomething, and
for no paſſion truly any thing, as boyes and women are
for the moſt part, cattle of this colour: would now like
him, now loath him: then entertaine him, then forſwear
him: now weepe for him, then ſpit at him; that I draue
my Sutor from his mad humor of loue, to a liuing humor
of madnes, ẃ was to forſweare the ful ſtream of ý world,
and to liue in a nooke meerly Monaſtick: and thus I cur’d
him, and this way wil I take vpon mee to waſh your Li-
uer as cleane as a ſound ſheepes heart, that there ſhal not
be one ſpot of Loue in’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I would not be cured, youth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I would cure you, if you would but call me Roſa-
lind, and come euerie day to my Coat, and woe me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orlan.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by the faith of my loue, I will; Tel me
where it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Go with me to it, and Ile ſhew it you: and by
the way, you ſhal tell me, where in the Forreſt you liue:
Wil you go?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart, good youth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, you muſt call mee Roſalind: Come ſiſter,
will you go?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Come apace good Audrey, I wil fetch vp your
Goates, Audrey: and how Audrey am I the man yet?
Doth my ſimple feature content you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aud.
SPEECH.LINE: Your features, Lord warrant vs: what features?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I am heere with thee, and thy Goats, as the moſt
capricious Poet honeſt Ouid was among the Gothes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: O knowledge ill inhabited, worſe then Ioue in
a thatch’d houſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: When a mans verſes cannot be vnderſtood, nor
a mans good wit ſeconded with the forward childe, vn-
derſtanding: it ſtrikes a man more dead then a great rec-
koning in a little roome: truly, I would the Gods hadde
made thee poeticall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aud.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not know what Poetical is: is it honeſt in
deed and word: is it a true thing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: No trulie: for the trueſt poetrie is the moſt fai-
ning, and Louers are giuen to Poetrie: and what they
ſweare in Poetrie, may be ſaid as Louers, they do feigne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aud.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you wiſh then that the Gods had made me
Poeticall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: I do truly: for thou ſwear’ſt to me thou art ho-
neſt: Now if thou wert a Poet, I might haue ſome hope
thou didſt feigne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aud.
SPEECH.LINE: Would you not haue me honeſt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: No truly, vnleſſe thou wert hard fauour’d: for
honeſtie coupled to beautie, is to haue Honie a ſawce to
Sugar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: A materiall foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aud.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I am not faire, and therefore I pray the
Gods make me honeſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly, and to caſt away honeſtie vppon a foule
ſlut, were to put good meate into an vncleane diſh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aud.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not a ſlut, though I thanke the Goddes I
am foule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, praiſed be the Gods, for thy foulneſſe; ſlut-
tiſhneſſe may come heereafter. But be it, as it may bee,
I wil marrie thee: and to that end, I haue bin with Sir
Oliuer Mar-text, the Vicar of the next village, who hath
promis’d to meete me in this place of the Forreſt, and to
couple vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: I would faine ſee this meeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aud.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel, the Gods giue vs ioy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen. A man may if he were of a fearful heart,
ſtagger in this attempt: for heere wee haue no Temple
but the wood, no aſſembly but horne-beaſts. But what
though? Courage. As hornes are odious, they are neceſ-
ſarie. It is ſaid, many a man knowes no end of his goods;
right: Many a man has good Hornes, and knows no end
of them. Well, that is the dowrie of his wife, ’tis none
of his owne getting; hornes, euen ſo poore men alone:
No, no, the nobleſt Deere hath them as huge as the Raſ-
call: Is the ſingle man therefore bleſſed? No, as a wall’d
Towne is more worthier then a village, ſo is the fore-
head of a married man, more honourable then the bare
brow of a Batcheller: and by how much defence is bet-
ter then no ſkill, by ſo much is a horne more precious
then to want.
Heere comes Sir Oliuer: Sir Oliuer Mar-text you are
wel met. Will you diſpatch vs heere vnder this tree, or
ſhal we go with you to your Chappell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there none heere to giue the woman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil not take her on guift of any man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly ſhe muſt be giuen, or the marriage is not
lawfull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Proceed, proceede: Ile giue her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Good euen good Mr what ye cal’t: how do you
Sir, you are verie well met: goddild you for your laſt
companie, I am verie glad to ſee you, euen a toy in hand
heere Sir: Nay, pray be couer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Wil you be married, Motley?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: As the Oxe hath his bow ſir, the horſe his curb,
and the Falcon her bels, ſo man hath his deſires, and as
Pigeons bill, ſo wedlocke would be nibling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: And wil you (being a man of your breeding) be
married vnder a buſh like a begger? Get you to church,
and haue a good Prieſt that can tel you what marriage is,
this fellow wil but ioyne you together, as they ioyne
Wainſcot, then one of you wil proue a ſhrunke pannell,
and like greene timber, warpe, warpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not in the minde, but I were better to bee
married of him then of another, for he is not like to mar-
rie me wel: and not being wel married, it wil be a good
excuſe for me heereafter, to leaue my wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe thou with mee,
And let me counſel thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſweete Audrey,
We muſt be married, or we muſt liue in baudrey:
Farewel good Mr Oliuer: Not O ſweet Oliuer, O braue
Oliuer leaue me not behind thee: But winde away, bee
gone I ſay, I wil not to wedding with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis no matter; Ne’re a fantaſtical knaue of them
all ſhal flout me out of my calling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer talke to me, I wil weepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Do I prethee, but yet haue the grace to conſider,
that teares do not become a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: But haue I not cauſe to weepe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: As good cauſe as one would deſire,
Therefore weepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: His very haire
Is of the diſſembling colour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Something browner then Iudaſſes:
Marrie his kiſſes are Iudaſſes owne children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I’faith his haire is of a good colour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: An excellent colour:
Your Cheſſenut was euer the onely colour:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And his kiſſing is as ful of ſanƈtitie,
As the touch of holy bread.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee hath bought a paire of caſt lips of Diana: a
Nun of winters ſiſterhood kiſſes not more religiouſlie,
the very yce of chaſtity is in them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: But why did hee ſweare hee would come this
morning, and comes not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay certainly there is no truth in him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe you thinke ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, I thinke he is not a picke purſe, nor a horſe-
ſtealer, but for his verity in loue, I doe thinke him as
concaue as a couered goblet, or a Worme-eaten nut.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Not true in loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, when he is in, but I thinke he is not in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue heard him ſweare downright he was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Was, is not is: beſides, the oath of Louer is no
ſtronger then the word of a Tapſter, they are both the
confirmer of falſe reckonings, he attends here in the for-
reſt on the Duke your father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I met the Duke yeſterday, and had much que-
ſtion with him: he askt me of what parentage I was; I
told him of as good as he, ſo he laugh’d and let mee goe.
But what talke wee of Fathers, when there is ſuch a man
as Orlando?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: O that’s a braue man, hee writes braue verſes,
ſpeakes braue words, ſweares braue oathes, and breakes
them brauely, quite trauers athwart the heart of his lo-
uer, as a puiſny Tilter, ý ſpurs his horſe but on one ſide,
breakes his ſtaffe like a noble gooſe; but all’s braue that
youth mounts, and folly guides: who comes heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corin.
SPEECH.LINE: Miſtreſſe and Maſter, you haue oft enquired
After the Shepheard that complain’d of loue,
Who you ſaw ſitting by me on the Turph,
Praiſing the proud diſdainfull Shepherdeſſe
That was his Miſtreſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: and what of him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: If you will ſee a pageant truely plaid
Betweene the pale complexion of true Loue,
And the red glowe of ſcorne and prowd diſdaine,
Goe hence a little, and I ſhall conduƈt you
If you will marke it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: O come, let vs remoue,
The ſight of Louers feedeth thoſe in loue:
Bring vs to this ſight, and you ſhall ſay
Ile proue a buſie aƈtor in their play.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Phebe doe not ſcorne me, do not Phebe
Say that you loue me not, but ſay not ſo
In bitterneſſe; the common executioner
Whoſe heart th’accuſtom’d ſight of death makes hard
Falls not the axe vpon the humbled neck,
But firſt begs pardon: will you ſterner be
Then he that dies and liues by bloody drops?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: I would not be thy executioner,
I flye thee, for I would not iniure thee:
Thou tellſt me there is murder in mine eye,
’Tis pretty ſure, and very probable,
That eyes that are the frailſt, and ſofteſt things,
Who ſhut their coward gates on atomyes,
Should be called tyrants, butchers, murtherers.
Now I doe frowne on thee with all my heart,
And if mine eyes can wound, now let them kill thee:
Now counterfeit to ſwound, why now fall downe,
Or if thou canſt not, oh for ſhame, for ſhame,
Lye not, to ſay mine eyes are murtherers:
Now ſhew the wound mine eye hath made in thee,
Scratch thee but with a pin, and there remaines
Some ſcarre of it: Leane vpon a ruſh
The Cicatrice and capable impreſſure
Thy palme ſome moment keepes: but now mine eyes
Which I haue darted at thee, hurt thee not,
Nor I am ſure there is no force in eyes
That can doe hurt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: O deere Phebe,
If euer (as that euer may be neere)
You meet in ſome freſh cheeke the power of fancie,
Then ſhall you know the wouunds inuiſible
That Loues keene arrows make.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: But till that time
Come not thou neere me: and when that time comes,
Affliƈt me with thy mockes, pitty me not,
As till that time I ſhall not pitty thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And why I pray you? who might be your mother
That you inſult, exult, and all at once
Ouer the wretched? what though you haue no beauty
As by my faith, I ſee no more in you
Then without Candle may goe darke to bed:
Muſt you be therefore prowd and pittileſſe?
Why what meanes this? why do you looke on me?
I ſee no more in you then in the ordinary
Of Natures ſale-worke? ’ods my little life,
I thinke ſhe meanes to tangle my eies too:
No faith proud Miſtreſſe, hope not after it,
’Tis not your inkie browes, your blacke ſilke haire,
Your bugle eye-balls, nor your cheeke of creame
That can entame my ſpirits to your worſhip:
You fooliſh Shepheard, wherefore do you follow her
Like foggy South, puffing with winde and raine,
You are a thouſand times a properer man
Then ſhe a woman. ’Tis ſuch fooles as you
That makes the world full of ill-fauourd children:
’Tis not her glaſſe, but you that flatters her,
And out of you ſhe ſees her ſelfe more proper
Then any of her lineaments can ſhow her:
But Miſtris, know your ſelfe, downe on your knees
And thanke heauen, faſting, for a good mans loue;
For I muſt tell you friendly in your eare,
Sell when you can, you are not for all markets:
Cry the man mercy, loue him, take his offer,
Foule is moſt foule, being foule to be a ſcoffer.
So take her to thee Shepheard, fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet youth, I pray you chide a yere together,
I had rather here you chide, then this man wooe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Hees falne in loue with your foulneſſe, & ſhee’ll
Fall in loue with my anger. If it be ſo, as faſt
As ſhe anſweres thee with frowning lookes, ile ſauce
Her with bitter words: why looke you ſo vpon me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: For no ill will I beare you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you do not fall in loue with mee,
For I am falſer then vowes made in wine:
Beſides, I like you not: if you will know my houſe,
’Tis at the tufft of Oliues, here hard by:
Will you goe Siſter? Shepheard ply her hard:
Come Siſter: Shepheardeſſe, looke on him better
And be not proud, though all the world could ſee,
None could be ſo abus’d in ſight as hee.
Come, to our flocke,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Dead Shepheard, now I find thy ſaw of might,
Who euer lov’d, that lou’d not at firſt ſight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Phebe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Hah: what ſaiſt thou Siluius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Phebe pitty me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Why I am ſorry for thee gentle Siluius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Where euer ſorrow is, reliefe would be:
If you doe ſorrow at my griefe in loue,
By giuing loue your ſorrow, and my griefe
Were both extermin’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou haſt my loue, is not that neighbourly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: I would haue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that were couetouſneſſe:
Siluius; the time was, that I hated thee;
And yet it is not, that I beare thee loue,
But ſince that thou canſt talke of loue ſo well,
Thy company, which erſt was irkeſome to me
I will endure; and Ile employ thee too:
But doe not looke for further recompence
Then thine owne gladneſſe, that thou art employd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: So holy, and ſo perfeƈt is my loue,
And I in ſuch a pouerty of grace,
That I ſhall thinke it a moſt plenteous crop
To gleane the broken eares after the man
That the maine harueſt reapes: looſe now and then
A ſcattred ſmile, and that Ile liue vpon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Knowſt thou the youth that ſpoke to mee yerewhile?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Not very well, but I haue met him oft,
And he hath bought the Cottage and the bounds
That the old Carlot once was Maſter of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Thinke not I loue him, though I ask for him,
’Tis but a peeuiſh boy, yet he talkes well,
But what care I for words? yet words do well
When he that ſpeakes them pleaſes thoſe that heare:
It is a pretty youth, not very prettie,
But ſure hee’s proud, and yet his pride becomes him;
Hee’ll make a proper man: the beſt thing in him
Is his complexion: and faſter then his tongue
Did make offence, his eye did heale it vp:
He is not very tall, yet for his yeeres hee’s tall:
His leg is but ſo ſo, and yet ’tis well:
There was a pretty redneſſe in his lip,
A little riper, and more luſtie red
Then that mixt in his cheeke: ’twas iuſt the difference
Betwixt the conſtant red, and mingled Damaske.
There be ſome women Siluius, had they markt him
In parcells as I did, would haue gone neere
To fall in loue with him: but for my part
I loue him not, nor hate him not: and yet
Haue more cauſe to hate him then to loue him,
For what had he to doe to chide at me?
He ſaid mine eyes were black, and my haire blacke,
And now I am remembred, ſcorn’d at me:
I maruell why I anſwer’d not againe,
But that’s all one: omittance is no quittance:
Ile write to him a very tanting Letter,
And thou ſhalt beare it, wilt thou Siluius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Phebe, with all my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile write it ſtrait:
The matter’s in my head, and in my heart,
I will be bitter with him, and paſſing ſhort;
Goe with me Siluius.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Roſalind, and Celia, and Iaques.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: I prethee, pretty youth, let me better acquainted
with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſay you are a melancholly fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſo: I doe loue it better then laughing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Thoſe that are in extremity of either, are abho-
minable fellowes, and betray themſelues to euery mo-
derne cenſure, worſe then drunkards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, ’tis good to be ſad and ſay nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then ’tis good to be a poſte.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue neither the Schollers melancholy, which
is emulation: nor the Muſitians, which is fantaſticall;
nor the Courtiers, which is proud: nor the Souldiers,
which is ambitious: nor the Lawiers, which is politick:
nor the Ladies, which is nice: nor the Louers, which
is all theſe: but it is a melancholy of mine owne, com-
pounded of many ſimples, extraƈted from many obieƈts,
and indeed the ſundrie contemplation of my trauells, in
which by often rumination, wraps me in a moſt humo-
rous ſadneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: A Traueller: by my faith you haue great rea-
ſon to be ſad: I feare you haue ſold your owne Lands,
to ſee other mens; then to haue ſeene much, and to haue
nothing, is to haue rich eyes and poore hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, I haue gain’d my experience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And your experience makes you ſad: I had ra-
ther haue a foole to make me merrie, then experience to
make me ſad, and to trauaile for it too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Good day, and happineſſe, deere Roſalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then God buy you, and you talke in blanke
verſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell Mounſieur Trauellor: looke you
liſpe, and weare ſtrange ſuites; diſable all the benefits
of your owne Countrie: be out of loue with your
natiuitie, and almoſt chide God for making you that
countenance you are; or I will ſcarce thinke you haue
ſwam in a Gundello. Why how now Orlando, where
haue you bin all this while? you a louer? and you
ſerue me ſuch another tricke, neuer come in my ſight
more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: My faire Roſalind, I come within an houre of my
promiſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Breake an houres promiſe in loue? hee that
will diuide a minute into a thouſand parts, and breake
but a part of the thouſand part of a minute in the affairs
of loue, it may be ſaid of him that Cupid hath clapt
him oth’ ſhoulder, but Ile warrant him heart hole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me deere Roſalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, and you be ſo tardie, come no more in my
ſight, I had as liefe be woo’d of a Snaile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Of a Snaile?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I, of a Snaile: for though he comes ſlowly, hee
carries his houſe on his head; a better ioynƈture I thinke
then you make a woman: beſides, he brings his deſtinie
with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Why hornes: ẃ ſuch as you are faine to be be-
holding to your wiues for: but he comes armed in his
fortune, and preuents the ſlander of his wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Vertue is no horne-maker: and my Roſalind is
vertuous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And I am your Roſalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: It pleaſes him to call you ſo: but he hath a Roſa-
lind of a better leere then you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, wooe me, wooe mee: for now I am in a
holy-day humor, and like enough to conſent: What
would you ſay to me now, and I were your verie, verie
Roſalind?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I would kiſſe before I ſpoke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, you were better ſpeake firſt, and when you
were grauel’d, for lacke of matter, you might take oc-
caſion to kiſſe: verie good Orators when they are out,
they will ſpit, and for louers, lacking (God warne vs)
matter, the cleanlieſt ſhift is to kiſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: How if the kiſſe be denide?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſhe puts you to entreatie, and there begins
new matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Who could be out, being before his beloued
Miſtris?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie that ſhould you if I were your Miſtris,
or I ſhould thinke my honeſtie ranker then my wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: What, of my ſuite?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Not out of your apparrell, and yet out of your
ſuite:
Am not I your Roſalind?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I take ſome ioy to ſay you are, becauſe I would
be talking of her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, in her perſon, I ſay I will not haue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Then in mine owne perſon, I die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: No faith, die by Attorney: the poore world is
almoſt ſix thouſand yeeres old, and in all this time there
was not anie man died in his owne perſon (videlicet) in
a loue cauſe: Troilous had his braines daſh’d out with a
Grecian club, yet he did what hee could to die before,
and he is one of the patternes of loue. Leander, he would
haue liu’d manie a faire yeere though Hero had turn’d
Nun; if it had not bin for a hot Midſomer-night, for
(good youth) he went but forth to waſh him in the Hel-
leſpont, and being taken with the crampe, was droun’d,
and the fooliſh Chronoclers of that age, found it was
Hero of Ceſtos. But theſe are all lies, men haue died
from time to time, and wormes haue eaten them, but not
for loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I would not haue my right Roſalind of this mind,
for I proteſt her frowne might kill me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: By this hand, it will not kill a flie: but come,
now I will be your Roſalind in a more comming-on diſ-
poſition: and aske me what you will, I will grant it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Then loue me Roſalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes faith will I, fridaies and ſaterdaies, and all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: And wilt thou haue me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and twentie ſuch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaieſt thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you not good?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosalind.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then, can one deſire too much of a
good thing: Come ſiſter, you ſhall be the Prieſt, and
marrie vs: giue me your hand Orlando: What doe you
ſay ſiſter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray thee marrie vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot ſay the words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: You muſt begin, will you Orlando.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe too: wil you Orlando, haue to wife this Ro-
ſalind?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but when?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Why now, as faſt as ſhe can marrie vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Then you muſt ſay, I take thee Roſalind for
wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I take thee Roſalind for wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I might aske you for your Commiſſion,
But I doe take thee Orlando for my husband: there’s a
girle goes before the Prieſt, and certainely a Womans
thought runs before her aƈtions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: So do all thoughts, they are wing’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Now tell me how long you would haue her, af-
ter you haue poſſeſt her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: For euer, and a day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Say a day, without the euer: no, no Orlando, men
are Aprill when they woe, December when they wed:
Maides are May when they are maides, but the sky chan-
ges when they are wiues: I will bee more iealous of
thee, then a Barbary cocke-pidgeon ouer his hen, more
clamorous then a Parrat againſt raine, more new-fang-
led then an ape, more giddy in my deſires, then a mon-
key: I will weepe for nothing, like Diana in the Foun-
taine, & I wil do that when you are diſpos’d to be merry:
I will laugh like a Hyen, and that when thou art inclin’d
to ſleepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: But will my Roſalind doe ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: By my life, ſhe will doe as I doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: O but ſhe is wiſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Or elſe ſhee could not haue the wit to doe this:
the wiſer, the waywarder: make the doores vpon a wo-
mans wit, and it will out at the caſement: ſhut that, and
’twill out at the key-hole: ſtop that, ’twill flie with the
ſmoake out at the chimney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: A man that had a wife with ſuch a wit, he might
ſay, wit whether wil’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, you might keepe that checke for it, till you
met your wiues wit going to your neighbours bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: And what wit could wit haue, to excuſe that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry to ſay, ſhe came to ſeeke you there: you
ſhall neuer take her without her anſwer, vnleſſe you take
her without her tongue: ô that woman that cannot
make her fault her huſbands occaſion, let her neuer nurſe
her childe her ſelfe, for ſhe will breed it like a foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: For theſe two houres Roſalinde, I wil leaue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, deere loue, I cannot lacke thee two houres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I muſt attend the Duke at dinner, by two a clock
I will be with thee againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I, goe your waies, goe your waies: I knew what
you would proue, my friends told mee as much, and I
thought no leſſe: that flattering tongue of yours wonne
me: ’tis but one caſt away, and ſo come death: two o’
clocke is your howre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I, ſweet Roſalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth, and in good earneſt, and ſo God
mend mee, and by all pretty oathes that are not dange-
rous, if you breake one iot of your promiſe, or come one
minute behinde your houre, I will thinke you the moſt
patheticall breake-promiſe, and the moſt hollow louer,
and the moſt vnworthy of her you call Roſalinde, that
may bee choſen out of the groſſe band of the vnfaith-
full: therefore beware my cenſure, and keep your pro-
miſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: With no leſſe religion, then if thou wert indeed
my Roſalind: ſo adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, Time is the olde Iuſtice that examines all
ſuch offenders, and let time try: adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue ſimply miſus’d our ſexe in your loue-
prate: we muſt haue your doublet and hoſe pluckt ouer
your head, and ſhew the world what the bird hath done
to her owne neaſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: O coz, coz, coz: my pretty little coz, that thou
didſt know how many fathome deepe I am in loue: but
it cannot bee ſounded: my affeƈtion hath an vnknowne
bottome, like the Bay of Portugall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Or rather bottomleſſe, that as faſt as you poure
affeƈtion in, it runs out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: No, that ſame wicked Baſtard of Venus, that was
begot of thought, conceiu’d of ſpleene, and borne of
madneſſe, that blinde raſcally boy, that abuſes euery
ones eyes, becauſe his owne are out, let him bee iudge,
how deepe I am in loue: ile tell thee Aliena, I cannot be
out of the ſight of Orlando: Ile goe finde a ſhadow, and
ſigh till he come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel
SPEECH.LINE: And Ile ſleepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is he that killed the Deare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, it was I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Let’s preſent him to the Duke like a Romane
Conquerour, and it would doe well to ſet the Deares
horns vpon his head, for a branch of viƈtory; haue you
no ſong Forreſter for this purpoſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Sing it: ’tis no matter how it bee in tune, ſo it
make noyſe enough.

SCENE.LINE: What ſhall he haue that kild the Deare?
His Leather skin, and hornes to weare:
Then ſing him home, the reſt ſhall beare this burthen;
Take thou no ſcorne to weare the horne,
It was a creſt ere thou waſt borne,
Thy fathers father wore it,
And thy father bore it,
The horne, the horne, the luſty horne,
Is not a thing to laugh to ſcorne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſay you now, is it not paſt two a clock?
And heere much Orlando.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant you, with pure loue, & troubled brain,
He hath t’ane his bow and arrowes, and is gone forth
To ſleepe: looke who comes heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: My errand is to you, faire youth,
My gentle Phebe, did bid me giue you this:
I know not the contents, but as I gueſſe
By the ſterne brow, and waſpiſh aƈtion
Which ſhe did vſe, as ſhe was writing of it,
It beares an angry tenure; pardon me,
I am but as a guiltleſſe meſſenger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Patience her ſelfe would ſtartle at this letter,
And play the ſwaggerer, beare this, beare all:
Shee ſaies I am not faire, that I lacke manners,
She calls me proud, and that ſhe could not loue me
Were man as rare as Phenix: ’od’s my will,
Her loue is not the Hare that I doe hunt,
Why writes ſhe ſo to me? well Shepheard, well,
This is a Letter of your owne deuice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I proteſt, I know not the contents,
Phebe did write it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, you are a foole,
And turn’d into the extremity of loue.
I ſaw her hand, ſhe has a leatherne hand,
A freeſtone coloured hand: I verily did thinke
That her old gloues were on, but twas her hands:
She has a huſwiues hand, but that’s no matter:
I ſay ſhe neuer did inuent this letter,
This is a mans inuention, and his hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Sure it is hers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, tis a boyſterous and a cruell ſtile,
A ſtile for challengers: why, ſhe defies me,
Like Turke to Chriſtian: vvomens gentle braine
Could not drop forth ſuch giant rude inuention,
Such Ethiop vvords, blacker in their effeƈt
Then in their countenance: vvill you heare the letter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: So pleaſe you, for I neuer heard it yet:
Yet heard too much of Phebes crueltie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: She Phebes me: marke how the tyrant vvrites.
Art thou god, to Shepherd turn’d?
That a maidens heart hath burn’d.
Can a vvoman raile thus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Call you this railing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros
SPEECH.LINE: Why, thy godhead laid a part,
War’ſt thou with a womans heart?
Did you euer heare ſuch railing?
Whiles the eye of man did wooe me,
That could do no vengeance to me.
Meaning me a beaſt.
If the ſcorne of your bright eine
Haue power to raiſe ſuch loue in mine,
Alacke, in me, what ſtrange effeƈt
Would they worke in milde aſpeƈt?
Whiles you chid me, I did loue,
How then might your praiers moue?
He that brings this loue to thee,
Little knowes this Loue in me:
And by him ſeale vp thy minde,
Whether that thy youth and kinde
Will the faithfull offer take
Of me, and all that I can make,
Or elſe by him my loue denie,
And then Ile ſtudie how to die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Call you this chiding?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas poore Shepheard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe you pitty him? No, he deſerues no pitty:
wilt thou loue ſuch a woman? what to make thee an in-
ſtrument, and play falſe ſtraines vpon thee? not to be en-
dur’d. Well, goe your way to her; (for I ſee Loue hath
made thee a tame ſnake) and ſay this to her; That if ſhe
loue me, I charge her to loue thee: if ſhe will not, I will
neuer haue her, vnleſſe thou intreat for her: if you bee a
true louer hence, and not a word; for here comes more
company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oliu.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, faire ones: pray you, (if you know)
Where in the Purlews of this Forreſt, ſtands
A ſheep-coat, fenc’d about with Oliue-trees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Weſt of this place, down in the neighbor bottom
The ranke of Oziers, by the murmuring ſtreame
Left on your right hand, brings you to the place:
But at this howre, the houſe doth keepe it ſelfe,
There’s none within.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: If that an eye may profit by a tongue,
Then ſhould I know you by deſcription,
Such garments, and ſuch yeeres: the boy is faire,
Of femall fauour, and beſtowes himſelfe
Like a ripe ſiſter: the woman low
And browner then her brother: are not you
The owner of the houſe I did enquire for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: It is no boaſt, being ask’d, to ſay we are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: Orlando doth commend him to you both,
And to that youth hee calls his Roſalind,
He ſends this bloudy napkin; are you he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I am: what muſt we vnderſtand by this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: Some of my ſhame, if you will know of me
What man I am, and how, and why, and where
This handkercher was ſtain’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you tell it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: When laſt the yong Orlando parted from you,
He left a promiſe to returne againe
Within an houre, and pacing through the Forreſt,
Chewing the food of ſweet and bitter fancie,
Loe vvhat befell: he threw his eye aſide,
And marke vvhat obieƈt did preſent it ſelfe
Vnder an old Oake, whoſe bows were moſs’d with age
And high top, bald with drie antiquitie:
A wretched ragged man, ore-growne with haire
Lay ſleeping on his back; about his necke
A greene and guilded ſnake had wreath’d it ſelfe,
Who with her head, nimble in threats approach’d
The opening of his mouth: but ſodainly
Seeing Orlando, it vnlink’d it ſelfe,
And with indented glides, did ſlip away
Into a buſh, vnder which buſhes ſhade
A Lyouneſſe, with vdders all drawne drie,
Lay cowching head on ground, with catlike watch
When that the ſleeping man ſhould ſtirre; for ’tis
The royall diſpoſition of that beaſt
To prey on nothing, that doth ſeeme as dead:
This ſeene, Orlando did approach the man,
And found it was his brother, his elder brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: O I haue heard him ſpeake of that ſame brother,
And he did render him the moſt vnnaturall
That liu’d amongſt men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: And well he might ſo doe,
For well I know he was vnnaturall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: But to Orlando: did he leaue him there
Food to the ſuck’d and hungry Lyonneſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: Twice did he turne his backe, and purpos’d ſo:
But kindneſſe, nobler euer then reuenge,
And Nature ſtronger then his iuſt occaſion,
Made him giue battell to the Lyonneſſe:
Who quickly fell before him, in which hurtling
From miſerable ſlumber I awaked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you his brother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Was’t you he reſcu’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Was’t you that did ſo oft contriue to kill him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Twas I: but ’tis not I: I doe not ſhame
To tell you what I was, ſince my conuerſion
So ſweetly taſtes, being the thing I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: But for the bloody napkin?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: By and by:
When from the firſt to laſt betwixt vs two,
Teares our recountments had moſt kindely bath’d,
As how I came into that Deſert place.
I briefe, he led me to the gentle Duke,
Who gaue me freſh aray, and entertainment,
Committing me vnto my brothers loue,
Who led me inſtantly vnto his Caue,
There ſtript himſelfe, and heere vpon his arme
The Lyonneſſe had torne ſome fleſh away,
Which all this while had bled; and now he fainted,
And cride in fainting vpon Roſalinde.
Briefe, I recouer’d him, bound vp his wound,
And after ſome ſmall ſpace, being ſtrong at heart,
He ſent me hither, ſtranger as I am
To tell this ſtory, that you might excuſe
His broken promiſe, and to giue this napkin
Died in this bloud, vnto the Shepheard youth,
That he in ſport doth call his Roſalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now Ganimed, ſweet Ganimed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: Many will ſwoon when they do look on bloud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: There is more in it; Coſen Ganimed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke, he recouers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I were at home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee’ll lead you thither:
I pray you will you take him by the arme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: Be of good cheere youth: you a man?
You lacke a mans heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe ſo, I confeſſe it:
Ah, ſirra, a body would thinke this was well counterfei-
ted, I pray you tell your brother how well I counterfei-
ted: heigh-ho.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: This was not counterfeit, there is too great te-
ſtimony in your complexion, that it was a paſſion of ear-
neſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Counterfeit, I aſſure you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: Well then, take a good heart, and counterfeit to
be a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: So I doe: but yfaith, I ſhould haue beene a wo-
man by right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cel.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, you looke paler and paler: pray you draw
homewards: good ſir, goe with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oli.
SPEECH.LINE: That will I: for I muſt beare anſwere backe
How you excuſe my brother, Roſalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall deuiſe ſomething: but I pray you com-
mend my counterfeiting to him: will you goe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhall finde a time Awdrie, patience gen-
tle Awdrie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Awd.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith the Prieſt was good enough, for all the
olde gentlemans ſaying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: A moſt wicked Sir Oliuer, Awdrie, a moſt vile
Mar-text. But Awdrie, there is a youth heere in the
Forreſt layes claime to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Awd.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I know who ’tis: he hath no intereſt in mee
in the world: here comes the man you meane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: It is meat and drinke to me to ſee a Clowne, by
my troth, we that haue good wits, haue much to anſwer
for: we ſhall be flouting: we cannot hold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Good eu’n Audrey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aud.
SPEECH.LINE: God ye good eu’n William.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: And good eu’n to you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Good eu’n gentle friend. Couer thy head, couer
thy head: Nay prethee bee couer’d. How olde are you
Friend?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue and twentie Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: A ripe age: Is thy name William?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: William, ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: A faire name. Was’t borne i’th Forreſt heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, I thanke God.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Thanke God: A good anſwer:
Art rich?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Faith ſir, ſo, ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: So, ſo, is good, very good, very excellent good:
and yet it is not, it is but ſo, ſo:
Art thou wiſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, I haue a prettie wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, thou ſaiſt well. I do now remember a ſay-
ing: The Foole doth thinke he is wiſe, but the wiſeman
knowes himſelfe to be a Foole. The Heathen Philoſo-
pher, when he had a deſire to eate a Grape, would open
his lips when he put it into his mouth, meaning there-
by, that Grapes were made to eate, and lippes to open.
You do loue this maid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: I do ſit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me your hand: Art thou Learned?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Then learne this of me, To haue, is to haue. For
it is a figure in Rhetoricke, that drink being powr’d out
of a cup into a glaſſe, by filling the one, doth empty the
other. For all your Writers do conſent, that ipſe is hee:
now you are not ipſe, for I am he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Which he ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſir, that muſt marrie this woman: Therefore
you Clowne, abandon: which is in the vulgar, leaue the
ſocietie: which in the booriſh, is companie, of this fe-
male: which in the common, is woman: which toge-
ther, is, abandon the ſociety of this Female, or Clowne
thou periſheſt: or to thy better vnderſtanding, dyeſt; or
(to wit) I kill thee, make thee away, tranſlate thy life in-
to death, thy libertie into bondage: I will deale in poy-
ſon with thee, or in baſtinado, or in ſteele: I will bandy
with thee in faƈtion, I will ore-run thee with policie: I
will kill thee a hundred and fifty wayes, therefore trem-
ble and depart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aud.
SPEECH.LINE: Do good William.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will
SPEECH.LINE: God reſt you merry ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Our Maſter and Miſtreſſe ſeekes you: come a-
way, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Trip Audry, trip Audry, I attend,
I attend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Is’t poſſible, that on ſo little acquaintance you
ſhould like her? that, but ſeeing, you ſhould loue her?
And louing woo? and wooing, ſhe ſhould graunt? And
will you perſeuer to enioy her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither call the giddineſſe of it in queſtion; the
pouertie of her, the ſmall acquaintance, my ſodaine wo-
ing, nor ſodaine conſenting: but ſay with mee, I loue
Aliena: ſay with her, that ſhe loues mee; conſent with
both, that we may enioy each other: it ſhall be to your
good: for my fathers houſe, and all the reuennew, that
was old Sir Rowlands will I eſtate vpon you, and heere
liue and die a Shepherd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue my conſent.
Let your Wedding be to morrow: thither will I
Inuite the Duke, and all’s contented followers:
Go you, and prepare Aliena; for looke you,
Heere comes my Roſalinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: God ſaue you brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.
SPEECH.LINE: And you faire ſiſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my deere Orlando, how it greeues me to ſee
thee weare thy heart in a ſcarfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: It is my arme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I thought thy heart had beene wounded with
the clawes of a Lion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Wounded it is, but with the eyes of a Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Did your brother tell you how I counterfeyted
to ſound, when he ſhew’d me your handkercher?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and greater wonders then that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: O, I know where you are: nay, tis true: there
was neuer any thing ſo ſodaine, but the ſight of two
Rammes, and Ceſars Thraſonicall bragge of I came, ſaw,
and ouercome. For your brother, and my ſiſter, no ſoo-
ner met, but they look’d: no ſooner look’d, but they
lou’d; no ſooner lou’d, but they ſigh’d: no ſooner ſigh’d
but they ask’d one another the reaſon: no ſooner knew
the reaſon, but they ſought the remedie: and in theſe
degrees, haue they made a paire of ſtaires to marriage,
which they will climbe incontinent, or elſe bee inconti-
nent before marriage; they are in the verie wrath of
loue, and they will together. Clubbes cannot part
them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſhall be married to morrow: and I will
bid the Duke to the Nuptiall. But O, how bitter a thing
it is, to looke into happines through another mans eies:
by ſo much the more ſhall I to morrow be at the height
of heart heauineſſe, by how much I ſhal thinke my bro-
ther happie, in hauing what he wiſhes for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then to morrow, I cannot ſerue your turne
for Roſalind?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I can liue no longer by thinking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I will wearie you then no longer with idle tal-
king. Know of me then (for now I ſpeake to ſome pur-
poſe) that I know you are a Gentleman of good conceit:
I ſpeake not this, that you ſhould beare a good opinion
of my knowledge: inſomuch (I ſay) I know you are: nei-
ther do I labor for a greater eſteeme then may in ſome
little meaſure draw a beleefe from you, to do your ſelfe
good, and not to grace me. Beleeue then, if you pleaſe,
that I can do ſtrange things: I haue ſince I was three
yeare old conuerſt with a Magitian, moſt profound in
his Art, and yet not damnable. If you do loue Roſalinde
ſo neere the hart, as your geſture cries it out: when your
brother marries Aliena, ſhall you marrie her. I know in-
to what ſtraights of Fortune ſhe is driuen, and it is not
impoſſible to me, if it appeare not inconuenient to you,
to ſet her before your eyes to morrow, humane as ſhe is,
and without any danger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: Speak’ſt thou in ſober meanings?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: By my life I do, which I tender deerly, though
I ſay I am a Magitian: Therefore put you in your beſt a-
ray, bid your friends: for if you will be married to mor-
row, you ſhall: and to Roſalind if you will.
Looke, here comes a Louer of mine, and a louer of hers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Youth, you haue done me much vngentleneſſe,
To ſhew the letter that I writ to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I care not if I haue: it is my ſtudie
To ſeeme deſpightfull and vngentle to you:
you are there followed by a faithful ſhepheard,
Looke vpon him, loue him: he worſhips you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Good ſhepheard, tell this youth what ’tis to loue

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: It is to be all made of ſighes and teares,
And ſo am I for Phebe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: And I for Ganimed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: And I for Roſalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And I for no woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: It is to be all made of faith and ſeruice,
And ſo am I for Phebe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: And I for Ganimed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: And I for Roſalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And I for no woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: It is to be all made of fantaſie,
All made of paſſion, and all made of wiſhes,
All adoration, dutie, and obſeruance,
All humbleneſſe, all patience, and impatience,
All puritie, all triall, all obſeruance:
And ſo am I for Phebe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo am I for Ganimed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo am I for Roſalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo am I for no woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: If this be ſo, why blame you me to loue you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: If this be ſo, why blame you me to loue you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: If this be ſo, why blame you me to loue you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do you ſpeake too, Why blame you mee
to loue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: To her, that is not heere, nor doth not heare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you no more of this, ’tis like the howling
of Iriſh Wolues againſt the Moone: I will helpe you
if I can: I would loue you if I could: To morrow meet
me altogether: I wil marrie you, if euer I marrie Wo-
man, and Ile be married to morrow: I will ſatisfie you,
if euer I ſatisfi’d man, and you ſhall bee married to mor-
row. I wil content you, if what pleaſes you contents
you, and you ſhal be married to morrow: As you loue
Roſalind meet, as you loue Phebe meet, and as I loue no
woman, Ile meet: ſo fare you wel: I haue left you com-
mands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile not faile, if I liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: To morrow is the ioyfull day Audrey, to morow
will we be married.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aud.
SPEECH.LINE: I do deſire it with all my heart: and I hope it is
no diſhoneſt deſire, to deſire to be a woman of ý world?
Heere come two of the baniſh’d Dukes Pages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1. Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel met honeſt Gentleman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth well met: come, ſit, ſit, and a ſong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2. Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: We are for you, ſit i’th middle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1. Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Shal we clap into’t roundly, without hauking,
or ſpitting, or ſaying we are hoarſe, which are the onely
prologues to a bad voice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2. Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: I faith, y’faith, and both in a tune like two
gipſies on a horſe.
It was a Louer, and his laſſe,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
That o’re the greene corne feild did paſſe,
In the ſpring time, the onely pretty rang time.
When Birds do ſing, hey ding a ding, ding.
Sweet Louers loue the ſpring,
And therefore take the preſent time.
With a hey, & a ho, and a hey nonino,
For loue is crowned with the prime.
In ſpring time, &c.
Betweene the acres of the Rie,
With a hey, and a ho, & a hey nonino:
Theſe prettie Country folks would lie.
In ſpring time, &c.
This Carroll they began that houre,
With a hey and a ho, & a hey nonino:
How that a life was but a Flower,
In ſpring time, &c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly yong Gentlemen, though there vvas no
great matter in the dittie, yet ý note was very vntunable

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1. Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: you are deceiu’d Sir, we kept time, we loſt not
our time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth yes: I count it but time loſt to heare
ſuch a fooliſh ſong. God buy you, and God mend your
voices. Come Audrie.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Duke Senior, Amyens, Iaques, Orlando, Oliuer, Celia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du. Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: Doſt thou beleeue Orlando, that the boy
Can do all this that he hath promiſed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſometimes do beleeue, and ſomtimes do not,
As thoſe that feare they hope, and know they feare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Patience once more, whiles our cōpaƈt is vrg’d:
You ſay, if I bring in your Roſalinde,
You wil beſtow her on Orlando heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du. Se.
SPEECH.LINE: That would I, had I kingdoms to giue with hir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And you ſay you wil haue her, when I bring hir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: That would I, were I of all kingdomes King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſay, you’l marrie me, if I be willing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: That will I, ſhould I die the houre after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: But if you do refuſe to marrie me,
You’l giue your ſelfe to this moſt faithfull Shepheard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: So is the bargaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſay that you’l haue Phebe if ſhe will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Though to haue her and death, were both one
thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue promis’d to make all this matter euen:
Keepe you your word, O Duke, to giue your daughter,
You yours Orlando, to receiue his daughter:
Keepe you your word Phebe, that you’l marrie me,
Or elſe refuſing me to wed this ſhepheard:
Keepe your word Siluius, that you’l marrie her
If ſhe refuſe me, and from hence I go
To make theſe doubts all euen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du. Sen.
SPEECH.LINE: I do remember in this ſhepheard boy,
Some liuely touches of my daughters fauour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, the firſt time that I euer ſaw him,
Me thought he was a brother to your daughter:
But my good Lord, this Boy is Forreſt borne,
And hath bin tutor’d in the rudiments
Of many deſperate ſtudies, by his vnckle,
Whom he reports to be a great Magitian.
Obſcured in the circle of this Forreſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: There is ſure another flood toward, and theſe
couples are comming to the Arke. Here comes a payre
of verie ſtrange beaſts, which in all tongues, are call’d
Fooles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Salutation and greeting to you all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord, bid him welcome: This is the
Motley-minded Gentleman, that I haue ſo often met in
the Forreſt: he hath bin a Courtier he ſweares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: If any man doubt that, let him put mee to my
purgation, I haue trod a meaſure, I haue flattred a Lady,
I haue bin politicke with my friend, ſmooth with mine
enemie, I haue vndone three Tailors, I haue had foure
quarrels, and like to haue fought one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: And how was that tane vp?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Faith we met, and found the quarrel was vpon
the ſeuenth cauſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſeuenth cauſe? Good my Lord, like this
fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du. Se.
SPEECH.LINE: I like him very well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: God’ild you ſir, I deſire you of the like: I preſſe
in heere ſir, amongſt the reſt of the Country copulatiues
to ſweare, and to forſweare, according as mariage binds
and blood breakes: a poore virgin ſir, an il-fauor’d thing
ſir, but mine owne, a poore humour of mine ſir, to take
that that no man elſe will: rich honeſtie dwels like a mi-
ſer ſir, in a poore houſe, as your Pearle in your foule oy-
ſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du. Se.
SPEECH.LINE: By my faith, he is very ſwift, and ſententious

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: According to the fooles bolt ſir, and ſuch dulcet
diſeaſes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: But for the ſeuenth cauſe. How did you finde
the quarrell on the ſeuenth cauſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon a lye, ſeuen times remoued: (beare your
bodie more ſeeming Audry) as thus ſir: I did diſlike the
cut of a certaine Courtiers beard: he ſent me word, if I
ſaid his beard was not cut well, hee was in the minde it
was: this is call’d the retort courteous. If I ſent him
word againe, it was not well cut, he wold ſend me word
he cut it to pleaſe himſelfe: this is call’d the quip modeſt.
If againe, it was not well cut, he diſabled my iudgment:
this is called, the reply churliſh. If againe it was not well
cut, he would anſwer I ſpake not true: this is call’d the
reproofe valiant. If againe, it was not well cut, he wold
ſay, I lie: this is call’d the counter-checke quarrelſome:
and ſo to lye circumſtantiall, and the lye direƈt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: And how oft did you ſay his beard was not well
cut?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I durſt go no further then the lye circumſtantial:
nor he durſt not giue me the lye direƈt: and ſo wee mea-
ſur’d ſwords, and parted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Can you nominate in order now, the degrees of
the lye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſir, we quarrel in print, by the booke: as you
haue bookes for good manners: I will name you the de-
grees. The firſt, the Retort courteous: the ſecond, the
Quip-modeſt: the third, the reply Churliſh: the fourth,
the Reproofe valiant: the fift, the Counterchecke quar-
relſome: the ſixt, the Lye with circumſtance: the ſea-
uenth, the Lye direƈt: all theſe you may auoyd, but the
Lye direƈt: and you may auoide that too, with an If. I
knew when ſeuen Iuſtices could not take vp a Quarrell,
but when the parties were met themſelues, one of them
thought but of an If; as if you ſaide ſo, then I ſaide ſo:
and they ſhooke hands, and ſwore brothers. Your If, is
the onely peace-maker: much vertue in if.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not this a rare fellow my Lord? He’s as good
at any thing, and yet a foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du. Se.
SPEECH.LINE: He vſes his folly like a ſtalking-horſe, and vn-
der the preſentation of that he ſhoots his wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hymen.
SPEECH.LINE: Then is there mirth in heauen,
When earthly things made eauen
attone together.
Good Duke receiue thy daughter,
Hymen from Heauen brought her,
Yea brought her hether.
That thou mightſt ioyne his hand with his,
Whoſe heart within his boſome is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: To you I giue my ſelfe, for I am yours.
To you I giue my ſelfe, for I am yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du. Se.
SPEECH.LINE: If there be truth in ſight, you are my daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Orl.
SPEECH.LINE: If there be truth in ſight, you are my Roſalind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: If ſight & ſhape be true, why then my loue adieu

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile haue no Father, if you be not he:
Ile haue no Husband, if you be not he:
Nor ne’re wed woman, if you be not ſhee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hy.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace hoa: I barre confuſion,
’Tis I muſt make concluſion
Of theſe moſt ſtrange euents:
Here’s eight that muſt take hands,
To ioyne in Hymens bands,
If truth holds true contents.
You and you, no croſſe ſhall part;
You and you, are hart in hart:
You, to his loue muſt accord,
Or haue a Woman to your Lord.
You and you, are ſure together,
As the Winter to fowle Weather:
Whiles a Wedlocke Hymne we ſing,
Feede your ſelues with queſtioning:
That reaſon, wonder may diminiſh
How thus we met, and theſe things finiſh.
Wedding is great Iunos crowne,
O bleſſed bond of boord and bed:
’Tis Hymen peoples euerie towne,
High wedlock then be honored:
Honor, high honor and renowne
To Hymen, God of euerie Towne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du. Se.
SPEECH.LINE: O my deere Neece, welcome thou art to me,
Euen daughter welcome, in no leſſe degree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Phe.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil not eate my word, now thou art mine,
Thy faith, my fancie to thee doth combine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2. Bro.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me haue audience for a word or two:
I am the ſecond ſonne of old Sir Rowland,
That bring theſe tidings to this faire aſſembly.
Duke Frederick hearing how that euerie day
Men of great worth reſorted to this forreſt,
Addreſt a mightie power, which were on foote
In his owne conduƈt, purpoſely to take
His brother heere, and put him to the ſword:
And to the skirts of this wilde Wood he came;
Where, meeting with an old Religious man,
After ſome queſtion with him, was conuerted
Both from his enterprize, and from the world:
His crowne bequeathing to his baniſh’d Brother,
And all their Lands reſtor’d to him againe
That were with him exil’d. This to be true,
I do engage my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du. Se.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome yong man:
Thou offer’ſt fairely to thy brothers wedding:
To one his lands with-held, and to the other
A land it ſelfe at large, a potent Dukedome.
Firſt, in this Forreſt, let vs do thoſe ends
That heere vvete well begun, and wel begot:
And after, euery of this happie number
That haue endur’d ſhrew’d daies, and nights with vs,
Shal ſhare the good of our returned fortune,
According to the meaſure of their ſtates.
Meane time, forget this new-falne dignitie,
And fall into our Ruſticke Reuelrie:
Play Muſicke, and you Brides and Bride-groomes all,
With meaſure heap’d in ioy, to’th Meaſures fall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, by your patience: if I heard you rightly,
The Duke hath put on a Religious life,
And throwne into negleƈt the pompous Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2. Bro.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: To him will I: out of theſe conuertites,
There is much matter to be heard, and learn’d:
you to your former Honor, I bequeath
your patience, and your vertue, well deſerues it.
you to a loue, that your true faith doth merit:
you to your land, and loue, and great allies:
you to a long, and well-deſerued bed:
And you to wrangling, for thy louing voyage
Is but for two moneths viƈtuall’d: So to your pleaſures,
I am for other, then for dancing meazures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du. Se.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, Iaques, ſtay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: To ſee no paſtime, I: what you would haue,
Ile ſtay to know, at your abandon’d caue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du. Se.
SPEECH.LINE: Proceed, proceed: wee’l begin theſe rights,
As we do truſt, they’l end in true delights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not the faſhion to ſee the Ladie the Epi-
logue: but it is no more vnhandſome, then to ſee the
Lord the Prologue. If it be true, that good wine needs
no buſh, ’tis true, that a good play needes no Epilogue.
Yet to good wine they do vſe good buſhes: and good
playes proue the better by the helpe of good Epilogues:
What a caſe am I in then, that am neither a good Epi-
logue, nor cannot inſinuate with you in the behalfe of a
good play? I am not furniſh’d like a Begger, therefore
to begge will not become mee. My way is to coniure
you, and Ile begin with the Women. I charge you (O
women) for the loue you beare to men, to like as much
of this Play, as pleaſe you: And I charge you (O men)
for the loue you beare to women (as I perceiue by your
ſimpring, none of you hates them) that betweene you,
and the women, the play may pleaſe. If I were a Wo-
man, I would kiſſe as many of you as had beards that
pleas’d me, complexions that lik’d me, and breaths that
I defi’de not: And I am ſure, as many as haue good
beards, or good faces, or ſweet breaths, will for my kind
offer, when I make curt’ſie, bid me farewell.
